fields.indicator: b'Restricted to authorized personnel only.'
b'PPE available and worn properly.'
b'Decon area separate from clean activities and accessible by a door or pass through window.'
b'Doors kept closed.'
b'Clean/free of improper items, e.g. debris, shipping boxes, fans, foods, drinks.'
b'Floors, walls, ceilings and work surfaces constructed of material that can withstand daily or more frequent cleaning.'
b'Handwashing facilities conveniently located with dispensers filled to allow for proper handwashing.'
b'Temperature and humidity controlled and recorded by facility or property services daily (72-78/22-26).'
b'Are the temperature and humidity levels within the acceptable ranges? T= 60-65\xc2\xb0F Decontamination; H = 30-60% in work areas; Not over 70% in sterile storage areas.'
b'Appropriate devices used to maintain temperature and humidity levels.'
b'Minimum of double sink for clinics (wash and rinse).'
b'Well defined workflow: Dirty to Clean (approved signage in place). '
b'Differential airflow in soiled utility/decon room, Negative'
b'Differential airflow verified by property services technician annually.'
b'PPE removed and hand hygiene performed before leaving dirty area'
b'PPE supplies readily available.'
b'All jewelry is removed and hair covers are worn consistently and not hair is visible.'
b'Minimum of triple sink for SPD '
b'Eyewash stations located within 10 seconds travel time and are unobstructed. '
b'Equipment maintenance records maintained.'
b'Manager can speak to ventilation requirements. Verifies with property services that ventilation is appropriate 10 air exchanges per hour. '
b'Processing area kept free of food and drink.'
b'Appropriate cleaning and decontamination solutions. Dilution-measuring cups and lines in sink for accurate measuring. Expiration dates and solution containers labeled.'

b'Appropriate cleaning process used. Sharps and delicates separate. No use of saline on instruments. Cleaning happens as soon as possible. Instruments kept moist until cleaned. Not cleaned in hand sinks or scrub sinks. Brushing occurs in water.'
b'Restricted to authorized personnel only.'
b'Restricted to authorized personnel only.'
b'PPE available and worn properly.'
b'Are the temperature and humidity levels within the acceptable ranges? T=68-73\xc2\xb0 F Clean areas; H = 30-60% in work areas; Not over 70% in sterile storage areas.'
b'Temperature and humidity controlled and recorded by facility or property services daily (72-78/22-26).'
b'Appropriate devices used to maintain temperature and humidity levels.'
b'Differential airflow in clean utility room, Positive'
b'Differential airflow where sterile and/or HLD instruments are stored, Positive.'
b'Differential airflow verified by property services technician semi-annually.'
b'Differential airflow in procedure room, Positive. Room is labeled and used to perform procedures not done in regular exam room.'
b'Doors kept closed.'
b'Clean/free of improper items, e.g. debris, shipping boxes, fans, foods, drinks.'
b'Floors, walls, ceilings and work surfaces constructed of material that can withstand daily or more frequent cleaning.'
b'Handwashing facilities conveniently located with dispensers filled to allow for proper handwashing.'
b'Eyewash stations located within 10 seconds travel time and are unobstructed.'
b'Equipment maintenance records maintained.'
b'Manager can speak to ventilation requirements. Verifies with property services that ventilation is appropriate 10 air exchanges per hour.'
b'Processing area kept free of food and drink.'

b"Manufacturer's instructions for use are available to staff for each medical device processed that requires decontamination, high level disinfection and low level disinfection and staff is following MFG IFU recommendations"
b'Formal documented continuing education and training program for each staff member listing their competencies and improvement plans on file and up to date.'
b'Transport algorithm(s) in all appropriate exam/procedure rooms.'
b'Processing algorithm(s) current and posted in soiled and clean utility room and in all appropriate exam/procedure rooms.'
b'Staff knows where to locate P & P'

b'Policies and Procedures are current according to best practice: Dress code, Care and handling of instruments, Packaging systems, Sterilization recall, Sterilization identification, Sterile storage, Chemical disinfectants (including HLD), Shelf life (event related), PM for equipment, Sterilization- steam and low temp, Endoscopes-cleaning and processing, Environmental cleaning, Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), Single use devices.'
b'Policies and procedures are followed and monitored.'
b'Cleaning immediately after procedure in procedure room for Endocavity Probes.'
b'Performs hand hygiene and don PPE (gloves).'
b'Wipes probe after completion of the procedure with MFG approved wipe to remove all excess gel from the transducer.'
b'Uses a second wipe to wipe probe to end of power cord. Uses friction and works from cleanest to dirtiest section.'
b'Dries the transducer with single-use cloth or wipe (e.g. clean single use disposable procedure towel)'
b'Disposes wipes and PPE in regular trash.'
b'Places probe in the appropriate container tagged with white tag and closes lid.'
b'Removes PPE, performs hand hygiene and don clean gloves.'
b'Follows Transporting Clean Medical Devices from Procedure Room to HLD room/area Algorithm.'
b'Performs hand hygiene & don PPE- (impervious long sleeved gown, surgical mask, eye protection, bouffant, gloves).'
b'Places pan/basin lined with chuck to absorb enzymatic flush and water flush on table used for sterile field. (after procedure table is considered dirty).'
b'Removes Endozime SLR sponge from Endozime SLR bedside care kit.'
b'Wipes exterior surface of scope, starting with the top of the insertion tube to end of insertion tube with Endozime SLR sponge.'
b'Discards sponge in waste pan/basin or regular trash.'
b'Uses a 30cc syringe to suck up 30cc of Endozime SLR from jar.'
b'Flushes lumen of scope with Endozime SLR solution X3.'
b'Collects waste in pan/basin.'
b'Disassembles stop cock and places in culture cup with enough enzymatic solution to completely cover stop cock.'
b'Uses a 30cc syringe to suck up 30cc of water from culture cup. (disposes daily)'
b'Flushes lumen of scope with water X3'
b'Collects waste in pan/basin.'
b'Uses 30cc syringe, flushes lumen of scope with air X3.'
b'Discards waste pan/basin and syringe in regular trash.'
b'Places the scope into the lined transport/SPD collection container and closes lid.'
b'Confirms there is a biohazard sticker or appropriate red biohazard tag on outside of transport/SPD collection container.'
b'Removes PPE, performs hand hygiene and don clean gloves.'
b'Follows Transporting Dirty Scope from Procedure Room to Soiled Utility Room or SPD Algorithm.'
b'Performs hand hygiene & don PPE (impervious long sleeved gown, surgical mask, eye protection, bouffant, gloves).'
b'Removes Endozime SLR sponge from Phase One canister.'
b'Wipes exterior surface of scope, starting with the top of the insertion tube to end of insertion tube with Endozime SLR sponge soaked in prepared enzymatic solution.'
b'Discards sponge in regular trash.'

b'Places the distal end of the endoscope into the Phase One canister and suctions the Endozime SLR enzymatic solution through the biopsy/suction channel until container is empty. (minimual 30 seconds)'
b'Disassembles stop cock/valve (if using reusable) and places in transport container. Disposable stop cock/valve is discard in regular trash.'
b'Flushes water and air into the air/water channel in accordance with the endoscope manufacturers instructions. Lumened medical devices are flushed and wiped down per MFG IFU.'
b'Places the scope into transport container and closes lid.'
b'Confirms there is an appropriate biohazard indication on outside of transport container.'
b'Removes PPE, performs hand hygiene and don clean gloves.'
b'Transports Dirty scope from Procedure Room to Soiled Utility Room.'
b'Performs hand hygiene & don PPE (impervious long sleeved gown, surgical mask, eye protection, bouffant, gloves).'
b'Places pan/basin lined with chuck/disposable procedure towel to absorb water flush on table used for sterile field. (after procedure table is considered dirty).'
b'Removes a RTU Enzymatic Wipe from the container.'
b'Wipes exterior surface of scope, starting with the top of the insertion tube to end of insertion tube with Enzymatic Wipe.'
b'Discards wipe in pan/basin.'
b'Uses a 5cc syringe to suck up 5cc of water from culture cup.'
b'Flushes each lumen of scope with 5cc of water (three lumens).'
b'Collects waste in pan/basin.'
b'Discards ban/basin and syringe and culture cup in regular trash.'
b'Places the scope into the lined transport/SPD collection container and closes lid.'
b'Confirms there is a biohazard sticker or appropriate red biohazard tag on outside of transport/SPD collection container.'
b'Removes PPE, performs hand hygiene and don clean gloves.'
b'Follows Transporting Dirty Scope from Procedure Room to Soiled Utility Room or SPD Algorithm.'
b'Performs hand hygiene & don PPE (gloves).'
b'Removes a RTU Enzymatic Wipe from the container.'
b'Wipes exterior surface of scope, starting with the top of the insertion tube to end of insertion tube with Enzymatic Wipe.'
b'Discards wipe in regular trash.'
b'Places medical device into the lined transport/SPD collection container and closes lid.'
b'Confirms there is a biohazard sticker or appropriate red biohazard tag on outside of transport/SPD collection container.'
b'Removes PPE, performs hand hygiene and don clean gloves.'
b'Follows Transporting Dirty Instrument from Procedure Room to Soiled Utility Room or SPD Algorithm.'
b'Wipes grossly soiled instruments with appropriate wipe and discards in regular trash.'
b'Places the instruments into the lined transport/SPD collection container and closes lid.'
b'Confirms there is a biohazard sticker or appropriate red biohazard tag on outside of transport/SPD collection container.'
b'Removes PPE, performs hand hygiene and don clean gloves.'
b'Follows Transporting Dirty Medical Devices from Procedure Room to Soiled Utility Room or SPD Algorithm.'
b'Staff performs hand hygiene and don clean gloves.'
b'Instruments are in the open position when placed in transport container?'
b'Staff places the scope and culture cup containing the disassembled stop cock into the lined transport/SPD collection container and closes lid.'
b'Staff completing SPD request form for medical device sterilization correctly for transport to SPD or SPD pick up?'
b'Staff verifying that a biohazard sticker is on the outside of the SPD collection container and that the container is lined?'
b'Staff verifying that the appropriate biohazard tag is fastened to the transport container.'
b'Staff transports dirty reusable medical devices to soiled utility room or SPD in a lined covered container labeled with a biohazard sticker or appropriate biohazard tag.'

b'Staff transporting very small dirty medical devices in a zip lock bag and putting in the lined transport container with biohazard sticker or appropriate biohazard tag and transporting to soiled utility room or SPD.'
b'Staff removes liner from transport container and discards into regular trash.'

b'Staff decontaminates transport container between use with approved disinfectant and returns clean bin to designated storage area (using correct contact time). SPD should run container through washer (if size allows). If container is too large for washer, conatiner should be manually washed and wiped with alcohol wipe. Clean containers should be stored on clean side of SPD until picked up/used for transport.'
b'Staff placing pt. sticker inside transport container.'
b'All MFG stickers have been removed from transport containers used for internal transport of dirty medical devices.'
b'Doff PPE and perform hand hygiene.'
b'Staff doff PPE and perform hand hygiene. Staff don appropriate PPE (clean gloves).'
b'Staff removes medical device from lined transport container and places into lined collection container (areas processing on site) or SPD collection container.'
b'Staff saturates dirty medical device with Pre-Klenz spray ensuring that all instruments are in the open position.'
b'Staff ensures there is a biohazard sticker on outside of SPD collection container.'
b'Staff doff PPE and perform hand hygiene before leaving soiled utility room.'
b'Staff removes all jewelry, performs hand hygiene & don PPE (impervious long sleeved gown, surgical mask, eye protection, bouffant and gloves).'
b'Staff removes all jewelry, performs hand hygiene & don PPE (impervious long sleeved gown, surgical mask, eye protection, bouffant and gloves).'
b'Staff pressurizes scope 30 seconds (monitoring to make sure needle does not move)'

b'Staff moves the deflection lever up and done several times and turn the focus ring stop to stop while watching the pressure gauge. Continues with leak test if needle does not move. If needle moves contacts MFG or follows MFG IFU.'
b'Staff fills basin/sink with clean water, enough to completely submerge scope.'

b'Staff curls the light guide and insertion tube and submerges the entire scope. Moves the deflection lever up and down several times looking for bubbles, checks the following areas: Control Knob; Insertion tube: Distal tip, the valve ports and the connectors.'
b'Staff removes scope from water and depressurize scope. Removes leak tester from scope. Indicator needle should be at zero.'
b'Staff adds appropriate amount of enzymatic solution to leak testing water per MFG IFU.'
b'Staff checks water temperature of enzymatic solution per MFG IFU.'
b'Staff removes all jewelry, performs hand hygiene & don PPE (impervious long sleeved gown, surgical mask, eye protection, bouffant and gloves)'
b'Staff fills basin with clean water, enough to completely submerge scope.'
b'Staff plugs leak tester into maintenance unit (MU-1).'
b'Staff turns on MU-1.'
b'Staff depresses button at end of leak tester and listens for air flow.'
b'Staff attaches scope.'
b'Staff pressurizes scope for 30 seconds.'
b'Staff submerges pressurized scope in clean water for 30 seconds, completely submerges in clear water and looks for bubbles.'
b'Staff bends tip and watches for bubbles. If bubbles present keeps scope pressurized and proceeds to manual cleaning.'
b'Staff removes scope from water.'
b'Staff turns off MU-1.'
b'Staff detaches leak tester from MU-1 and listens for air.'
b'Staff disconnects scope from leak tester.'
b'Staff adds appropriate amount of enzymatic solution to leak testing water per MFG IFU.'
b'Staff checks water temperature of enzymatic solution per MFG IFU. (90 to 140 degrees F)'
b'Staff removes all jewelry, performs hand hygiene & don PPE (impervious long sleeved gown, surgical mask, eye protection, bouffant and gloves)'
b'Scans Scope ID and connects scope.'
b'Follows MFG IFU for automated leak testing.'
b'Staff removes all jewelry, performs hand hygiene & don PPE (impervious long sleeved gown, surgical mask, eye protection, bouffant and gloves)'
b'Scans Scope ID and connects scope.'
b'Follows MFG IFU for automated leak testing.'
b'Staff removes all jewelry, performs hand hygiene & don PPE (impervious long sleeved gown, surgical mask, eye protection, bouffant and gloves)'
b'Scans Scope ID and connects scope.'
b'Follows MFG IFU for automated leak testing.'
b'Staff removes all jewelry, performs hand hygiene & don PPE (impervious long sleeved gown, surgical mask, eye protection, bouffant and gloves)'
b'Staff mixes enzymatic solution per MFG IFU'
b'Staff immerses the ultrasound transducer into the enzymatic solution before soaking and cleaning probe.'
b'Staff plugs probe adapter into the appropriate port on the ULT 2020 Leakage Tester.'
b'Staff plugs the Ultrasound Transducer Electrical Connector into the transducer adapter. The transducer electrical connector plug should click into place.'
b'Staff plugs duel prong conductivity probe into the appropriate port on the ULT 2020 Leakage Tester.'
b'Staff places duel prong conductivity probe into enzymatic solution.'
b'Staff turns on the ULT 2020 Leakage Tester'
b'Staff selects the "Full Test" button.'
b'Staff documents result of test in Cidex OPA QC log book.'
b'Staff removes probe from use if leak test fails and notifies NM and/or contacts MFG. Staff documents corrective action.'
b'Mix enzymatic detergent according to MFG IFU if applicable.'

b'Uses enzymatic dispenser to dispense enzymatic detergent. Uses measuring cup to mix enzymatic detergent to correct water to ounce ratio, if applicable. Staff can articulate proper dilution instructions.'
b'Container/sink/sonic machine marked with gallon(s) level.'
b'Container/sink/sonic machine is labeled with enzyme cleaner name, date and initials when enzyme cleaner is placed in the container/sink.'
b'Measures temp according to MFG IFU.'
b'Not reprocessing any single use devices.'
b'Pre-Klenz is rinsed from dirty medical device in dirty sink before placing in enzymatic.'
b'Channeled/lamented instruments are filled with enzymatic solution and are completely submerged and allowed to soak per MFG guidelines.'
b'Soaks medical device completely submerged per enzymatic detergent MFG guidelines. (5 minutes for V. Mueller, 1-5 minutes for Prolistica)'
b'Hinged instruments are left in the open position and those with removable parts are disassembled to smallest part.'
b'Sharps and delicates are separated'
b'Not using saline on instruments'
b'Cleaning happens as soon as possible'
b'Instruments kept moist until cleaned'
b'Instruments not cleaned in hand sinks or scrub sinks'
b'Brushes are disposable or decontaminated and HLD or sterilized daily.'
b'Enzymatic detergent is freshly prepared for one time use with each scope and discarded after one time use.'
b'Staff removes all jewelry, performs hand hygiene & don PPE (impervious long sleeved gown, surgical mask, eye protection, bouffant and gloves).'
b'Detaches all removable parts and places disassembled components in enzymatic and brushes disassembled components holes of valves to remove debris under water line.'
b'Submerges medical device completely in enzymatic solution. Scrubs all surfaces to remove debris under water line.'
b'Cleans inside the suction valve, suction channel, air water valve, biopsy port openings and all other channel openings, with a disposable scrub brush or lint-free applicator.'
b'Brushes the entire biopsy/suction channel system.'
b'Brushes in the direction of the distal tip from the biopsy port.'
b'Rinses the bristles of the brush each time exiting the medical device before retracting brush back through the channel.'
b'Repeats brushing until no debris is visible on the brush.'
b'Attaches cleaning adapters to the biopsy port. Flushes all channels with enzymatic detergent (follows MFG IFU for recommendations for number of times and solution amount per scope).'
b'Disposable brushes are discarded after each use.'

b'Reusable brushes are cleaned and HLD or Sterilized after each use. Replaces when bristles are worn. When not in use brushs hang to promote complete drying. Cleaning tools are accessible and available for each type/size scope.'
b'Discards enzymatic detergent solution after each use. Enzymatic solution should be discarded after each scope.'
b'Non-Channeled Medical Device(s)'
b'Staff removes all jewelry, performs hand hygiene & don PPE (impervious long sleeved gown, surgical mask, eye protection, bouffant and gloves).'
b'Detaches all removable parts and places disassembled components in enzymatic and brushes disassembled components holes of valves to remove debris under water line.'
b'Submerges medical device completely in enzymatic solution. Scrubs all surfaces to remove debris under water line.'
b'Disposable brushes are discarded after each use.'
b'Reusable brushes are cleaned and HLD or Sterilized after each use. Replaces when bristles are worn. When not in use brushs hang to promote complete drying.'
b'Discards enzymatic detergent solution after each use. Enzymatic solution should be discarded after each scope.'
b'Staff removes all jewelry, performs hand hygiene & don PPE (impervious long sleeved gown, surgical mask, eye protection, bouffant and gloves).'
b'Scrubs all surfaces with scrub brush or other cleaning tools under water line, paying special attention to serrated edges and other hard to reach places.'
b'Assures Printer is working appropriately (correct date and time). Verifies after each cycle.'
b'Checks Door gasket for wear and tear. Checks gasket is properly created in door frame. Inspects once a month.'
b'Cleans and disinfects under both door gaskets with a germicidal detergent once a month.'
b'Cleans debris screen as needed or after last cycle of the day.'
b'Removes water sliding inlet from connection and inspects for debris once a week.'
b'Cleans washer/disinfector exterior once a week.'
b'Inspects and cleans rotary spray arm assemblies once a week. Removes assemblies and cleans individual spray jets.'
b'Runs decontamination cycle if washer/disinfector has not been used for more than 24 hrs.'
b'Runs decontamination cycle once a week for each washer and wears appropriate PPE (Chemical gloves and eye protection).'
b'Wears appropriate PPE when replacing Chemical Container. (Chemical gloves and eye protection).'
b'Does not empty any remaining chemical product from the old chemical container into the new chemical container.'
b'Performs daily quality assurance procedure. Flow validation test and decontamination.'
b'Documents quality assurance test results using daily quality assurance log. (Flow validation test and decontamination of Scope Buddy).'
b'Inspects Scope Buddy connect tubing for holes, cracks or leaks, nicks. Replace if worn or damaged.'
b'Follows MFG IFU for endoscope detergent/enzymatic flush cycle. (scope should be immersed fully in fluid filled sink)'
b'Follows MFG IFU for purging endoscope after detergent/enzymatic flush cycle (removes detergent/enzymatic from endoscope channels)'
b'Follows MFG IFU for endoscope water rinse.'
b'Follows MFG IFU for end of day shutdown.'
b'Follows MFG IFU for decontamination contact time.'
b'Uses appropriate HLD decontamination solution for manual decontamination.'

b'Follows MFG IFU for non-use/storage of Scope Buddy overnight or weekend. (leave full of decontamination fluid or clean water to maintain decontamination, lubrication and to facilitate priming; tubing can be disconnected and Scope Buddy unit turned off.'
b'Degas ultrasonic machine before use. Refer to MFG-IFU for this step.'
b'Runs cycle per manufacturer s IFU.'
b'Removes medical device(s) from pan when cycle is complete.'
b'Performs daily quality assurance procedure using Ultrasonic indicator with correct number and placement of indicator.'
b'Rinses outside of medical device thoroughly in tap water as well as all removable parts.'
b'Rinses/flushes lumen/channel thoroughly with tap water'
b'Forces air through lumen/channel.'
b'Dries the medical device with a soft, lint-free cloth.'
b'Cleaning challenge test in place for channeled scopes.'
b'Cleaning challenge test for channeled scopes are being done per facility guidelines.'
b'Doff PPE (removes) and performs hand hygiene.'
b'Rinses outside of medical device thoroughly in tap water as well as all removable parts.'
b'Doff PPE (removes) and performs hand hygiene.'
b'Rinses outside of medical device thoroughly in tap water as well as all removable parts.'
b'Doff PPE (removes) and performs hand hygiene.'
b'Uses medical grade air to dry scope after AER cycle completed before hanging scope in scope cabinet.'
b'Air dries instruments on lint free material in clean room or designated clean area.'
b'Don clean gloves.'
b'Correctly uses lubricant spray according to MFG IFU.'
b'Prepares milk solution per MFG IFU in clean room or designated clean area.'
b'Container is marked with contents, date of preparation, expiration date (14 days post preparation) and initials.'
b'Solution is discarded if solution has separated, has gray tint or has reached expiration date.'
b'Soaking bin is washed and disinfected between each preparation.'
b'After cleaning, completely immerses hinged instruments and those with movable parts in a milk solution per MFG IFU.'
b'Remove (DO NOT RINSE) and allow to air dry on lint free material.'
b'Doff PPE (remove) and perform hand hygiene.'
b'Performs hand hygiene and don clean gloves and bouffant.'
b'Looks through the scope, adjusting the focus ring on the eyepiece as necessary to inspect image quality.'
b'Examines the scope, looking for areas of damage such as creases along the shaft or damage to the handle/eyepiece, holes tears, or other gross damage.'
b'Checks hinged medical device(s) for ease of opening and alignment of jaws and teeth.'
b'Checks sharp or semi-sharp medical device(s) for sharpness.'
b'Checks all medical device(s) for cracks, chips, sharp edges or worn spots.'
b'Checks malleable medical device(s) for dents and bends.'
b'Removes from service ANY medical device(s) with any defects and gives to appropriate person for repair.'
b'Inspects medical device(s) to ensure it is both clean and dry prior to HLD.'
b'Cleaning challenge test in place for medical devices.'
b'Cleaning challenge test for medical devices are being done per facility guidelines.'
b'Instruments in good condition.'
b'Instrument refurbishing plan.'
b'Doff (remove) PPE and performs hand hygiene.'
b'Packaging for Steam Sterilization'
b'Performs hand hygiene and don clean gloves and bouffant.'
b'Wrapped trays and/or rigid containers assembled without pouches or count sheets inside.'
b'Heavier instruments are always created or placed in the wrap first.'
b'Curved tips are always pointed in the same direction.'
b'Sharp tips are covered with gauze or special tip covers that have been validated for use.'
b'Cupped or concave instruments like basins or metal bowls are positioned to avoid water/condensation collection and to allow all surfaces exposure to sterilization.'
b'Instrument set weights not over 25 pounds.'
b'Internal and external CI used for all packages.'
b'Instrument refurbishing plan.'
b'Uses only the one-step wrap in appropriate size for contents. DO NOT CUT WRAP TO SIZE.'
b'Places the CI in the center of wrapped packages, and in two opposite corners of rigid containers. One end should be visible when pack opened and CI is placed on all levels.'
b'Places all instruments in the open position or disassembles instruments to their smallest parts.'
b'Secures with a MAXIMUM of 3 strips of appropriate steam indicator tape and tape is in good condition'
b'Wrapped pack labeled with date of sterilization, load number and initials of person preparing package. Label with special water-proof high heat tolerant pen: Sharpe 13601'
b'Instrument tape (if used) is in good condition.'
b'Not processing any single use devices (need to be FDA cleared).'
b'Instrument tracking system available.'
b'Selects appropriate size package and double peel packs are not folded.'
b'Places the CI in every package so it is visible from outside the pouch.'
b'Seal open end of package ensuring even seal without wrinkles and excessive air. Air acts as a barrier to heat and steam.'
b'Lighter items (peel packs) on top shelf'
b'Peel packs and linen packs are on edge (not horizontal) and not stacking.'
b'No stacking of pans (without manufacturers recommendations)'
b'Places all pouches in the same direction.'
b'BI run daily and results are documented'
b'Daily Bowie Dick. First run of the day. Empty chamber and results are documented.'
b'Same lot number is used for the control and the processed BI.'
b'Steam sterilization records storage follows the facilities record retention policy.'
b'Manufacturer recommendations readily available and followed.'
b'Extended cycles run per manufacturers recommendations.'
b'Implants monitored with BI and a Class 5 CI'
b'Implants not released until results of BI available.'
b'If implant released before BI available a release form is completed by all appropriate parties.'
b'Management of loaner instrumentation in place.'
b'All Steam sterilized items are traceable to the patient.'
b'Recall process in place and reported to Infection Control.'
b'Allow processed loads to cool properly.'
b'All QC logs are complete with CI, BI and Bowie Dick results where applicable.'
b'Sterilizer printouts observed, initialed and maintained for each sterilization cycle.'

b'Peel pack(on plastic side) and wrapped packs label with special water-proof high heat tolerant pen: Sharpe 13601  date of sterilization load contents Operators name Sterilizer identification type of sterilizer and cycle used lot control number load contents critical parameters for specific sterilization method  Results of the sterilization process monitors (physical, CI and BI). Sterilization tape initialed and dated and CI and BI results documented in appropriate log.'

b'Immediate Use Steam Sterilization practices:
\xe2\x96\xa1 Items are appropriately cleaned.
\xe2\x96\xa1 Use of closed flash containers.
\xe2\x96\xa1 All parameters documented.
\xe2\x96\xa1 Aseptic transportation to point of use
\xe2\x96\xa1 Implants: Bi & CI run with all implants and not released until results of BI available. If released, early release form completed by all appropriate parties.
\xe2\x96\xa1 Traceable to patient
\xe2\x96\xa1 IUSS not used as substitute for sufficient instrument inventory.'

b'Follow MFG-IFU directions for loading and operation of the autoclave ensuring that packs are loaded in a manner that allows for free steam and air circulation.\nM9 maximum number of peel pouches can load if using pouch size 3-1/2in X 9in is 6. One pouch on each small tray and two pouches on two large trays. Tray specs for M9 trays are Large: 7-5/16in X 12in x 7/8 in, Small tray 5-5/8in X 12in X 7/8 in. For wrapped trays ca not load anything larger than largest tray. M11 maximum number of peel pouches can load if using pouch sizes 5-1/4in x 10in is 6. Two pouches on large tray and 1 on small tray. With 3-1/2in X 9in is 10. Three pouches on large tray and 2 on small tray. Tray specs for M11 Large: 9in x 15in x 1-1/8in, Small 6-5/8in X 15in x 1-1/8in. For wrapped trays can not load anything larger than largest tray. Never overload TT sterilizer'
b'Set autoclave controls for the appropriate type of packaging.'

b'Staff can articulate reasons to resterilize instruments.  Failed BI \xe2\x96\xa1 Visible condensation. Note: repackages and resterilizes single package if only one; repackages and resterilizes entire load if more than 1 package affected. Never uses package with condensation. \xe2\x96\xa1 Package steam indicators have not changed to appropriate color.  \xe2\x96\xa1 Package integrity concerns, compromised storage and handling conditions.'
b'Staff can articulate where to find RECALL POLICY and when to implement RECALL POLICY.'
b'Notify appropriate supervisor and Healthcare Epidemiology of failed run.'
b'Completes failed run report and faxes or e-mails to Healthcare Epidemiology. Fax # 409-772-2337, mmguigne@utmb.edu.'
b'Does not EVER use the "Unwrapped or Flash" cycles.'
b'Sterilizer printouts observed, initialed and maintained for each sterilization cycle.'

b'All sterilizers tested with biological indicators, i.e. correct frequency and inside a PCD at least weekly. Place PCD in a full load in the coldest area of the sterilizer chamber. Normally this is "the center of the load towards the front of the chamber on bottom tray closest to drain.'
b'Stock appropriate autoclave cleaner and maintenance supplies. (distilled water and autoclave cleaner)'
b'Runs monthly pressure relief valve test and documents on appropriate log.'
b'Flushes TT sterilizer monthly with appropriate cleaner and documents on appropriate log.'
b'Checks and cleans chamber filters monthly and replaces filter when necessary and documents on appropriate log.'

b'Performs weekly cleaning on TT sterilizer, wipes external and internal surfaces with damp cloth and drains water from reservoir, cleans trays, door gasket, inside of chamber and metal surfaces and documents on appropriate log.'

b'Sterilizers retested (all modes, 3 consecutive times) after installation, major repairs or failures and relocation. This is called a Qualification Test and CES should tell you if repair is a major repair.'
b'Can staff can articulate when it is necessary to retest sterilizer (all modes) with three consecutive runs.'
b'Cleans chamber drain strainer once a day in the morning prior to first cycle. (Brushes and flushes strainer to remove any debris).'
b'Wipes down and rinses chamber following any spills or soiling. (Chamber is allowed to cool to room temperature by opening chamber emergency manual exhaust valve).'
b'Flushes chamber drain weekly or when line becomes clogged. (Turns off steam supply valve, waits until jacket pressure is at 0 psig, waits until unit is cooled to room temperature.'

b'Flushes chamber with appropriate solution. (60ml approx. 1/4 cup of Steris sonic detergent or Liquijet and 500ml approx. 1 pint of hot water into the drain may also use 15ml approx. 1 table spoon of tri-sodium phosphate to 500ml approx. 1 pint of hot water).'
b'Runs a daily biological monitor each day sterilizer(s) is used.'
b'Ensures CI monitor result is on file and logged for each package.'
b'V-Pro printouts observed, initialed and maintained for each V-Pro cycle.'
b'Biological indicators incubated correctly and results recorded after full incubation.'
b'Control (unprocessed) BI used daily and labeled with "C" for each incubated BI and from the same lot as the Test BI daily and results recorded.'
b'Uses appropriate cycle for instrument type.'
b'Never uses BI Challenge Pack for routine monitoring.'
b'Performs routine maintenance according to MFG IFU (daily-clean chamber, weekly-leak test, quality of printout, monthly-machine oil on chamber door hinge pin and quarterly-inspect gasket door)'
b'Selects the proper size wrap for the items to be sterilized.'
b'Selects the proper size and type of pouch and tubing that has been validated for use in the V-Pro system.'
b'Performs a weekly Leak test. (review printout and initial) (less than 0.3 torr/minute = pass)'
b'Ensures chamber interior is clean per MFG IFU before loading chamber.'
b'Wears appropriate PPE before loading Vaprox HC sterilant cup.(Goggles or face shield and chemical-resistant gloves).'
b'Checks expiration date of sterilant before installing in V-Pro Unit.'
b'Loads sterilant into V-Pro unit per MFG IFU.'
b'Ensures instruments and devices are cleaned and dried before loading into the V-Pro unit.'
b'Places load on shelf and slides shelf back into chamber, ensuring shelves are completely inside chamber before closing door.'
b'Does not stack trays within trays.'
b'Does not stack trays on top of other trays.'
b'Does not stack pouches on top of each other.'
b'Places pouches either horizontally on the 2 shelves or if possible, on edge with the transparent side of the pouch facing the opaque side of the other.'
b'Ensures loads placed into sterilizer do not exceed stated weight or lumens (number, size or type) depending on the Sterilization Cycle chosen.'
b'Verifies BI and CI is not expired'
b'Places BI in appropriate place inside sterilizer per MFG IFU. (Top Shelf) Never place the pouch on top of items being sterilized.'
b'Places BI into appropriate low temperature sterilization pouch.'
b'Places the CI in every package so it is visible from outside the pack/pouch.'
b'Closes chamber door and runs appropriate processing cycle.'
b'Load is reprocessed and repackaged when cycle is aborted.'
b'Uses Chemical-resistant gloves to remove items from the Sterilization Unit after a cycle has been aborted.'
b'Items which can be disassembled should be disassembled for sterilization.'
b'Attach venting cap to scope.'
b'A chemical indicator strip must be placed inside the package.'
b'Scope must have an external chemical indicator such as Sterrad indicator tape.'
b'Wrapped items should not have any gaps or openings. Peel packs are not permitted inside any wrapped tray.'
b'Load Control Sticker should be applied after Sterrad sterilization cycle is complete.'

b'Remove B1 from peel packaging. Using the tube crusher, squeeze the vial until glass media ampule has been crushed. Do not crush by hand because the broken glass may penetrate the B1 vial and lacerate fingers.'
b'Keep vial in a vertical position after it has been crushed.'
b'Label vial with date and load number and places in incubator.'
b'Incubate B1 in an approved incubator at 55-60 degrees Centigrade for (24 ) hours (STERRAD). At this time the temperature of the STERRAD incubator will be recorded.'
b'Crush an unprocessed vial to serve as a test Control, label with date, and place in same incubator as the processed vial.'
b'Sterrad NX Manual is available in department and staff can locate.'
b'Ensure that all documentation is complete: (All elements below must be documented).'
b'Date, time and type of procedure'
b'Patient s name and medical record number'
b'Physician name'
b'Specific procedure(s)'
b'Scope serial number or other identifier'
b'Type of scope'
b'Time In/Time Out of disinfectant (glutaraldehyde) if manually processing'
b'Operator initials'
b'HLD validation sticker is attached to each processed item.'
b'Scopes are reprocessed when there is no sticker present or when the scope is compromised.'
b'Doff PPE and performs hand hygiene. Don clean gloves.'
b'Checks the expiration date on hydrogen peroxide cartridge before use.'
b'Checks the expiration date of chemical indicator before use and ensures CI is stored correctly per MFG IFU.'
b'Stores Hydrogen Peroxide Cartridge upright at all times.'
b'Stores Hydrogen Peroxide Cartridge away from heat and in correct temperature range (59\xc2\xb0F-77\xc2\xb0F/15\xc2\xb0C-25\xc2\xb0C)'
b'QC Log completed with all necessary information.'
b'Ensures the Trophon EPR disinfectant is purged before moving the Trophon system.'
b'Removes cap from Hydrogen Peroxide Cartridge.'
b'Follows instruction on LCD screen.'
b'Allows disinfectant chamber door to open automatically. Does not force door to open.'
b'Correctly inserts Hydrogen Peroxide Cartridge into the cartridge chamber (neck first).'
b'Correctly closes cartridge chamber door (does not force door shut)'
b'Doff PPE and performs hand hygiene.'
b'Performs hand hygiene and don clean gloves.'
b'Follows instruction on LCD screen.'
b'Purges cartridge to ensure all disinfectant is removed if cartridge expires before disinfectant solution is completely used.'
b'Removes and loads waste container.'
b'Follows instruction on LCD screen (replace cartridge now).'
b'Removes empty cartridge by lifting cartridge out by exposed areas to avoid touching pierced areas.'
b'Does not shake or change the orientation of the cartridge.'
b'Disposes empty cartridge in regular trash.'
b'Doff PPE and performs hand hygiene.'

b'Correctly loads the clean, dry probe into the Trophon EPR disinfection chamber. (probe secured high in the chamber with tip of probe above embossed line and probe does not contact the chamber wall at any point.'
b'For curved probes checks the Trophon EPR Validated Probes list to see if CPP accessory is needed.'
b'Correctly places a CI in the CI holder on the floor of the device chamber, red side up.'
b'Starting the Disinfectant Cycle for Trophon System'
b'Correctly closes the door to the chamber.'
b'Follows the LCD screen message.'
b'Doff PPE and performs hand hygiene.'
b'Performs hand hygiene and don clean gloves.'
b'Correctly opens chamber door.'
b'Removes CI and checks CI color against the color chart on the CI carton and discards CI in regular trash.'
b'Removes label from printer and places in QC Log.'
b'Documents the result of CI on label in appropriate place.'
b'Verifies a successful HLD cycle by checking label for Trophon LCD disinfection status.'
b'Does not proceed unless the CI and Trophon LCD disinfection status result state "PASS"'
b'Removes and wipes the probe using a dry single use cloth.'
b'Closes the chamber door.'
b'Doff PPE and performs hand hygiene.'
b'QC logs are correctly filled with appropriate information.'
b'Completely immerses reusable medical device, including valves and removable parts if applicable, in disinfectant solution.'
b'Fill channel(s) with disinfectant solution.'
b'Immerses reusable medical device in disinfectant solution for appropriate time per MFG IFU.'
b'Doff (remove) PPE and performs hand hygiene.'
b'Staff uses cell phone or timer to track appropriate length of time reusable medical equipment is disinfected.'
b'Reusable medical device is disinfected at the appropriate temp (minimally 20\xc2\xb0C (68\xc2\xb0F) or higher.'
b'Perform hand hygiene and don PPE (impervious long sleeved gown, surgical mask, eye protection, bouffant, gloves).'
b'Returns to HLD room or area to remove reusable medical device from disinfectant when appropriate soak time is up.'
b'Removes medical device from disinfectant solution.'
b'Medical device is rinsed with sterile water or filtered tap water. Three one minute soaks with two gallons of water for each soak.'
b'Rinses channel(s) with sterile water or filtered tap water.'
b'After water rinse, flushes all channels with 70%-90% ethyl or isopropyl alcohol to facilitate drying.'
b'Visually check that all ports have flow during alcohol purge.'
b'Purges all channels with forced air including insertion tube and inner channels to facilitate drying.'
b'Remove all cleaning adapters and devices.'
b'A new syringe is used for each scope or instrument for alcohol flushing; tubing adapter for flushing should be disposable or should be high level disinfected after each scope.'
b'Dry the exterior and accessories with a soft, dry lint-free cloth or air dry.'
b'Removes reusable medical devices from disinfectant solution.'
b'Reusable medical devices is rinsed with sterile water or filtered tap water. Three one minute soaks with two gallons of water for each soak.'
b'Dries the exterior and accessories with a soft, dry lint-free cloth or place in a dryer.'
b'Removes reusable medical devices from disinfectant solution.'
b'Reusable medical devices is rinsed with sterile water or filtered tap water. Three one minute soaks with two gallons of water for each soak.'
b'Dries the exterior and accessories with a soft, dry lint-free cloth or place in a dryer.'
b'Removes reusable medical devices from disinfectant solution.'
b'Reusable medical devices is rinsed with sterile water or filtered tap water. Three one minute soaks with two gallons of water for each soak.'
b'Dries the exterior and accessories with a soft, dry lint-free cloth or place in a dryer.'
b'Diagnostic cycle is run each day before running a regular HLD Steris cycle.'
b'Uses container and tray to run a diagnostic cycle on Steris machine.'
b'Removes all standing water from the drip pan after each Steris cycle.'
b'Performs maintenance and checks on Steris machine each time machine is used.'
b'Checks that all quick connects are attached properly to scopes before starting a Steris cycle .'
b'Does not use S40 sterilant after MFG IFU expiration date.'
b'Wears appropriate PPE when handling S40 sterilant.'
b'Reviews and initials printout parameters for each Steris cycle (temp. 45.5-60\xc2\xb0C, Sterilant concentration \xe2\x89\xa5175, contact time 6 minutes).'
b'Keeps printout parameters for each Steris cycle or AER.'
b'Staff can verbalize correct parameters for successfully completing HLD cycle for time, S40 sterilant concentration and temperature for a Steris cycle.'

b'Are proper manufacturer recommended steps followed when utilizing Automated Scope Reprocessing Equipment? Can staff articulate all steps required including quality testing? Proper connectors, routine maintenance.'
b'Verify machine is on'
b'Opens water shut-off valve to the incoming water line. Water pressure is at least 40 psi.'
b'Ensure the server and LIO programs are running'
b'Check all O-rings on connector manifolds are present and undamaged. Medivator technical support 1-800-444-4729.'
b'Inspect connector blocks for wear and tear'
b'Closes water shut-off valve, except when waterline disinfection is being run as part of daily shutdown.'
b'Wipes down basins and lids as part of daily shutdown.'
b'Keeps lids open as part of daily shutdown.'
b'Removes basin drain screen and filter with hook at least once a week or as needed.'
b'Inspects and cleans basin drain screen and filter of any debris at least once a week or as needed.'
b'Lubricate O-rings with silicon oil'
b'Replaces basin drain filter monthly and documents for each side (A & B) when replaced'
b'Cleans reusable spray arm filter for each side (A& B) monthly and documents cleaning.'
b'Replaces 1 and 0.4 micron filters at least every three months or when PSI is 35 and documents change.'
b'Replaces 0.1 micron water filter (bacteria0retentive filter) at least every six months.'
b'Runs waterline disinfection after replacing 0.1 micron filter and documents disinfection was conducted.'
b'Replaces air filters X 4 (2 on each side) at least every six months and documents change.'
b'Replaces vapor management filter (if applicable) at lease every six months and documents change.'
b'PM performed at least annually.'
b'Operates Medivator per MFG IFU.'

b'Uses test strip correctly to test Rapicide Glutaraldehyde working solution prior to each use to be sure it is above the minimum effective concentration (MEC). Documents result. (does not use test strip past 120 days from opening teststrip bottle or MFG expiration which ever comes first)'
b'Performs Quality Control on new bottle of Test Strips according to MFG IFU and documents results. (logs on to medivator website and prints test strip validation certificate).'
b'Disinfectant solution bottles (A&B) are not used past 21 days from opening or MFG expiration which ever comes first.'
b'Daily'
b'Disinfectant cycle (QC log maintained and up to date)'
b'Runninging disinfectant cycle when filters are changed, when there is any break in water delivery to AER.'
b'Change filters (large blue ones X3, internal filters, co/inline filter or as needed (this filter, filters trash in detergent)'
b'Changing the water filter and air filter. Filters dated with change or expiration date.'
b'Running wild cycle (disinfectant cycle) each time water filter is changed or if water is shut off from system.'
b'Cleaning Rinse of catheter is done with water for 3 minutes in less than 113 degrees F or 45 degrees C.'
b'Disposes silicone tubing after each use.'
b'Cleans catheter with enzymatic cleaner per MFG IFU. Follows enzymatic cleaner MFG IFU. (Mixing, soaking etc.)'
b'Rinses catheter after enzymatic cleaner with continuous flow of water for 3 minutes in less than 113 degrees F or 45 degrees C.'
b'HLD Catheter per HLD MFG IFU (includes filling lumen of catheter if applicable).'
b'Rinses catheter after HLD with continuous flow of water for 3 minutes in less than 113 degrees F or 45 degrees C.'
b'Isopropyl Alcohol flush catheter lumen if applicable.'

b'Dries catheter per MFG IFU includes using syringe to push air through catheter lumen if applicable, pats catheter dry, does not attach removable parts (luer lock caps) to the catheter during storage.'
b'Stores dry catheter in protective case'

b'Staff Member recognizes scopes types, # of channels to be processed, ports, adapters, connectors. Scope manufacturers instructions currently processed are available: Gastroscope  Colonoscope  Colonoscope, Pedi Duodenoscope/ERCP  Ultrasound Scope  Choledochoscope  Sigmoidoscope  Hysteroscope  Cystoscope  Urteroscope  Bronchoscope  Laryngeal Intubation  Rhinolaryngoscope Other ___________________________________'

b'Proper Protective Personal Equipment is available for reprocessing and handling HLD (i.e. Nitrile, chemotherapy or butyl gloves are requires when working with HLD and safety goggles when handling HLD).'
b'Emergency Chemical Spill/Eye Wash/Shower within required reach and clearance.'
b'Scope cleaning challenge testing in place and is being completed on percentage of scopes per facility guidelines.'
b'Data files from AER(s) are downloaded per facility guidelines.'
b'Manual cleaning: 3 container process (wash/rinsing/disinfection) properly labeled.'

b'Reprocessing Equipment - AER/Reprocessing sink/leak tester/scope cabinet in working conditions; No leaks (sink faucets and drain); scope cabinet doors closing entirely; No supplies stored under the sink/s.'
b'Cleaning tools are single use, accessible and available for each type/size scope.'
b'Approved cleaning and disinfecting solutions.'
b'Operators Manual for AER available.'
b'Reprocessing sinks and containers for manual cleaning water level marked.'
b'Visible expiration date of High-Level disinfection solution in use (i.e. on AER reservoir/GUS unit).'
b'Minimum effective concentration of high-level disinfectant is tested according to MFG IFU. MEC testing before each use. (If applicable)'
b'Activation and deactivation of HLD is properly documented (i.e. passed/failed, lot , expiration date). (If applicable.)'
b'Reprocessing Logs (scope reprocessing, scope cabinet cleaning, MEC testing) are regularly monitored and verified for task completion and accuracy purposes.'
b'Manual and Electronic scopes reprocessing logs (AER are reconciled with procedure cases (GI Clinic setting).'

b'Manual and Electronic scopes reprocessing logs reflects the required 7 elements as minimum: Patient Name Medical Record Procedure Type Scope Serial Scope Type Provider Name Date of Procedure Equipment use (AER/Manual)'
b'Point of Use Pre-cleaning performed according to MFG IFU.'

b'Staff can speak to the following process that applies to his/her area: scope initial inspection (including scope accessories) \xe2\x96\xa1 leak testing: Dry and/or Wet (if applicable) \xe2\x96\xa1 pre-cleaning: fresh cleaning solution, brushing and purging scope channels, and rinsing\xe2\x96\xa1 Manual/automated disinfection\xe2\x96\xa1 Alcohol rinse: follow scope MFG IFU \xe2\x96\xa1 Prepare for use/transportation or storage\xe2\x96\xa1 HLD label date/initials and/or expiration date\xe2\x96\xa1 Self disinfection of AER'
b'Process in place to identify last date scopes were processed.'
b'Aseptic technique in place to remove scope from scope cabinet.'
b'Process in place to properly transport scopes from/to reprocessing area.'
b'Process in place to identify, process and document scopes going to/from repair.'
b'Defined equipment preventive maintenance program in place.'
b'Data files from automated leakage tester are documented per facility guidelines.'
b'Each AER printout is initialed and kept for Pass or fail, cycle completed, cycle interruption, MEC entered.'
b'Performs hand hygiene.'
b'Transport HLD or Sterilized Reusable Medical Devices in container with appropriate HLD indication to the exam/procedure room or storage area.'
b'Don PPE (gloves) and wipes transport container with appropriate wipe.'
b'Remove PPE and performs hand hygiene.'

b'Scopes after high level disinfection hang vertically in a well ventilated cabinet specifically designed for scopes, to facilitate drying. Removes control valves, distal hoods, caps, etc. and store removable parts separately but should be kept with scope as a unique set. Note: some video scopes made by Pentax need a venting cap in place during storage. There should be adequate space to keep the scopes and other equipment from coming into contact with each other. (DO NOT STORE IN CASE). If scope is not stored appropriately, scope must be reprocessed just prior to use starting from pre-cleaning through the disinfection and rinse/drying steps.'
b'Disinfected scope is used immediately or stored in a manner to minimize recontamination.'
b'Uses new sterile water bottle and sterile disposable tubing assembly each day (smart cap).'

b'Sterilize or high-level disinfect all non-disposable semi-critical items (items that touch mucous membranes). Follow high level disinfection with three water rinses. A final alcohol rinse must be done for channeled scopes.\n---- Suction Adapter, Air-Water Adapter, Biopsy Adapter, Door Clamp-large or small types. Sterilize all non-disposable critical items (items that enter sterile tissue).\n---Biopsy forceps (sterilize or use disposable)'
b'Scopes used for sterile procedures must be reprocessed just prior to use:\nMust include pre-cleaning through the disinfection and rinse steps.'
b'Scope is stored with the angulation locks in the free position.'
b'Stores sterile instruments in separate area from clean supplies.'
b'Stores sterile instruments in bins or dust free storage shelves sorted by instrument type. Stores to prevent damage to packaging and compromise sterility. Doesnt overload bins or carts or shelves.'
b'Rotates sterile instruments oldest to newest.'
b'Heavy wrapped trays are not stacked and are on clean, dust-free storage shelves.'
b'Staff does not store compromised sterile packages and staff articulate reasons for resterilization.'
b'HLD reusable medical device(s) are individually wrapped.'
b'After HLD, endocavity probe(s) are stored in a manner to protect from damage or contamination. (Stored on Probe Rack with peel pack over probe).'
b'All items are 18" below the ceiling (or level of sprinkler head)'
b'5" above the floor'
b'2" from outside walls'
b'Cleanable surfaces'
b'No corrugated boxes found in clean, sterile storage room/closet.'
b'No corrugated boxes found in procedure rooms.'

b'Are non-critical items stored in clean storage closets or utility room (IV poles, ventilators, Bipap machines, bassinets patient lift equipment, scales, etc.) cleaned per PP and tagged or bagged to indicate that item is cleaned.'
b'US Gel without 30 day discard date.'
b'Can staff speak to how they know if a piece of equipment is clean.'
b'Bottom shelves are solid.'
b'Sterile items separated from clean items.'

b'Patient care items not stored under or beside sink'

b'Sharp containers 3/4 full'

b'Patient refrigerators clean with only patient food with open date.'
b'Hand Hygiene supplies available.'
b'Not dispensing patient care items from corrugated boxes.'
b'Walls and ceiling tiles are intact and free of holes and stains'
b'Dedicated clean equipment room (only clean, patient-ready equipment is stored)'
b'No dedicated clean equipment room (equipment should be bagged or tagged)'

b'Equipment and cords are wiped down, cords rolled and unplugged'
b'Equipment not used - place against the wall'

b'Eyewash station log (once a week)'
b'Dust all surfaces (equipment, nursess station, filing bins, etc.)'
b'Cardboard shipping boxes'
b'Sharp containers (3/4 full - replace)'
b'Drawers - separate clean from sterile supplies'
b'Equipment clearly identified as clean when not in use'
b'Nothing below 5" off the floor and 18" from the ceiling'
b'Remove tapes for ALL surfaces and equipment'
b'Warmer temperature for solutions at 104 degrees Farhenheit and 115 degrees Farenheit for blankets'
b'Solutions in the warmer expiration dates: Irrigation bottles expiration dates is 30 days, Flex bags expiration date is 14 days'
b'Checks behind bins to ensure no items fell off the back'
b'No back packs, lab coats or outside items'
b'Water stations must have non-spill containers'
b'No food within the redline areas including the radiology office'
b'Does not over stock Ors with pillows and other supplies. Bring in new supplies for each patient to avoid cross contamination'
b'Date open supplies - ECG pads, betadine and alcohol bottles'
b'Check code carts'
b'Check all equipment and surfaces for dust'
b'Supplies and medication outdates'
b'Unsecured medications'
b'Dispose all patient identifiers from the prior case'
b'Erase count boards after each case'
b'Wipe down all flat surfaces and surgical lights after every case'
b'Do not use multi-dose vials'
b'Megadyne pads in every room'
b'Room has basic equipment: Arm boards X 2, Patient rollers are off the floor, SCD cords are clean, Megadyne pad and cords are in place, Have risers available, Safety belt'

b'Check disinfection and sterilization records'
b'Cycle supplies and inventory'

b'Unsecured medication on the anesthesia carts'
